{{Infobox University |name = {{nowrap|Texas State University-San Marcos
Round Rock Higher Education Center}} |image_name = RR Primary H 3Color TRANS.png |image_size =160px |motto = |established = 2005{{cite web |url=http://www.rrhec.txstate.edu/about/story.html |title=Our Story: Round Rock Higher Education Center |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=May 17, 2011}} |type = Public |president = [[Denise Trauth]], Ph.D. |director = Edna Rehbein, Ph.D. |city = [[Round Rock]] |state = [[Texas]] |country = [[United States|USA]] |endowment = |enrollment = 1,984 (Fall 2010) |faculty = |campus = {{convert|110|acre|km2}} |former_names = |affiliations = |free = |free_label = |mascot = Boko the Bobcat |colors = Maroon and Gold |website = [http://www.rrhec.txstate.edu www.rrhec.txstate.edu] |footnotes = }} The '''Round Rock Higher Education Center''' (RRHEC) is the official name of [[Texas State University-San Marcos]]â campus in [[Round Rock, Texas]]. Located just {{convert|20|mi|km}} north of [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], it is informally referred to as "Texas State's Round Rock Campus." Construction began on the current campus in 2004 and opened its doors for the Fall semester in 2005. The campus hosts upper-level classes for eight bachelor's degrees and courses for eleven master's degrees and seven post bachelor's certificate programs. [[Image:RRHECpicFlowers.JPG|right|thumb|Avery Building at the Round Rock Higher Education Center]] == History == The Round Rock Higher Education Center started in 1996 and was housed in 15 portable buildings at the [[Westwood High School (Austin, Texas)|Westwood High School]] campus of the [[Round Rock Independent School District]]. Construction on a permanent campus, and the RRHEC's current location, began in 2004 with the {{convert|125,000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} Avery Building. The Avery Building opened its doors on August 26, 2005. In 2008, construction began on the campus' second building. The {{convert|77,740|sqft|m2|adj=on}} Nursing Building opened its doors in 2010. The campus currently sits on {{convert|101|acre|km2}} of property donated to Texas State University by the Avery family. == Academics == A student can earn one of eleven master's degrees or seven post bachelor's certificate's by taking courses solely at the Round Rock Higher Education Center. The student does not have to attend classes at Texas State's main campus in San Marcos. The RRHEC also offers upper level courses to allow students to complete one of eight bachelor's degrees. Lower level courses for the bachelor's degrees can be taken at Texas State's San Marcos campus or transfer the courses from a [[Community college#United States|community college]] or [[Junior college#United States|junior college]].{{cite web |url=http://www.rrhec.txstate.edu/about.html |title=About Us: Round Rock Higher Education Center |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=May 17, 2011 }} The degrees that can be earned at the RRHEC are:{{cite web |url=http://www.rrhec.txstate.edu/about/programs/bachelors.html |title=Bachelor's Degrees: Round Rock Higher Education Center |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=May 17, 2011 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.rrhec.txstate.edu/about/programs/masters.html |title=Master's Degrees: Round Rock Higher Education Center |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=May 17, 2011 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.rrhec.txstate.edu/about/programs/certificates.html |title=Certification and Continuing Education Programs: Round Rock Higher Education Center |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=May 17, 2011 }} ===College of Applied Arts=== '''Occupational Education Program''' *BA in Applied Arts and Sciences *MED in
